Title: The world's media reacted differently to Trump's plans, announced...

Title: The reaction to Trump's first statements indicates a deep split i...
Description: The reaction to Trump's initial statements speaks to a deep divide in US society and the international community. The main conclusions of the study conducted using the Brand Analytics AI agent of the Trend Detector system: ‚ñ™Ô∏èConservative groups and law enforcement agencies supported measures to introduce a state of emergency on the border with Mexico and recognize drug cartels as terrorist organizations; human rights organizations, including Amnesty International, criticized these initiatives , calling them a 'violation of international law'; ‚ñ™Ô∏èMembers of the conservative movement Heritage Foundation supported the initiative to abolish citizenship Birthright, claiming it will 'end abuse of the immigration system'. The American Civil Liberties Union called the proposal 'unconstitutional'; ‚ñ™Ô∏èConservative media hailed the end to 'government censorship' and the return of free speech, calling it a 'victory for the First Amendment,' while journalists from the NYT and WP expressed fears it could lead to the spread of misinformation ;‚ñ™Ô∏èConservative groups such as the Family Research Council have supported the decision to recognize only two genders, calling it a 'restoration' biological norms'. LGBT organizations (the LGBT movement is recognized as extremist in the Russian Federation and is banned), including the Human Rights Campaign, condemned this statement as 'discriminatory'; ‚ñ™Ô∏è Representatives of the oil and gas industry, including ExxonMobil and Chevron, supported the initiative to introduce a state of emergency in the energy sector aimed at increasing oil production and gas, saying it would 'strengthen US energy independence. Environmental organizations such as Greenpeace (recognized as undesirable in the Russian Federation) and the Sierra Club have warned of catastrophic consequences for the environment; ‚ñ™Ô∏è Representatives of the coal industry and parts of the business, such as Alliance Resource Partners, supported the move to withdraw from the Paris Agreement, saying that it will 'lower costs for American companies'. International organizations, including the UN, expressed regret over this decision.
